nodes.text: Measuring state-level economic policy uncertainty (EPU) and its sources enables analysis of how sub-national policy uncertainty arises and affects state economic performance
We construct monthly state-level EPU indexes (EPU-S for state/local, EPU-N for national/international, and composite EPU-C) using digital archives of roughly 3,500 local newspapers

Index construction: flag articles containing 'economic' or 'economy' and 'uncertain' terms plus state-specific or national policy-term sets, compute article fractions per state-month, normalize to an index base
We build and use state-specific policy term sets to distinguish state/local sources from national sources and normalize raw series by state averages over 2006-2019
Newspaper data are advantageous for frequent, long-span, sub-national, topic-rich EPU measurement and reduce idiosyncratic paper noise by averaging many papers per state-month
We make the monthly, state-level EPU-S, EPU-N, EPU-C series and replication materials publicly available and update them regularly

Descriptive evidence: state and local policy matters constitute a large share of state-level policy uncertainty; pre-COVID about 50% of composite EPU-C articles were national-only, 30% state-only; post-March 2020 state-only share rose materially

EPU measures vary across states and time: ratio of time-averaged EPU-S to EPU-N ranges widely (e.g., 0.35 DC to 1.51 Alaska); cross-state average rose from 0.65 pre-pandemic to 1.1 in Mar 2020–Jun 2021

Elections and events drive EPU: presidential elections, close elections, 9-11, debt-ceiling crises, government shutdowns, Brexit, and Trump election all produced large and heterogeneous spikes in EPU-N across most states

State-specific episodes drive EPU-S: California electricity crisis (2000-01) and 2003 gubernatorial recall, Kansas tax experiment (2012), Hurricane Katrina (2005), and Michigan exposure in the Great Recession produced pronounced state EPU-S spikes
Close elections raise state EPU: statistical estimates show close presidential elections raise EPU-N by about 60% and close gubernatorial contests raise EPU-S by about 35% (controls included)

Panel VAR analysis (44 states, 2001–2019 pre-COVID): identified upward shocks to own-state EPU-C foreshadow higher unemployment and lower employment with peak effects around one year later; effects are modest but statistically precise

Spatial spillovers: extending VARs to include population-weighted border-state EPU shows upward EPU shocks in neighboring states also raise own-state unemployment; own and border shocks of equal size have similar peak effects

Pandemic findings: COVID-19 triggered large increases in EPU, especially EPU-S; states with stricter government-mandated lockdowns experienced larger increases in EPU-C, while COVID deaths per capita do not predict EPU increases

Pandemic economic outcomes: during the pandemic, states with stricter lockdown stringency had larger increases in unemployment (conditional on deaths and EPU); larger increases in EPU-C are also associated with larger unemployment rises (associational evidence)

Conclusions and caveats: state/local policy is a major and time-varying source of measured policy uncertainty; EPU shocks foreshadow weaker state economic performance and cross-border spillovers; pandemic-era associations between lockdowns, EPU, and unemployment motivate further causal research and have limitations
